title: Two-Way Table
question_text: Which of the following situations would best be modeled in a two-way table?

choices.text: Determine if a new drug gives better pain relief (rated on a $1$ to $10$ scale) when compared to a control group.
Determine if there is a correlation between weight and height.
Determine if there is an association between gender and political preference.
Determine if using a bowling glove yields higher bowling scores.
Determine if this year has higher rainfall than last year.

solution:
Two-way tables always represent categorical data. Categorical data measures data that can fit into specific categories, as opposed to quantitative data that has respondents reply with a number.

Choice 'C' is correct; the variables of gender and political preference are both categorical.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. Pain relief, according to the answer, is measured on a scale of 1âˆ’10. Since numbers are used to describe the data, this data is quantitative, not categorical.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. Both weight and height are quantitative variables; therefore a two-way table would not make sense.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. Bowling scores are quantitative (some number between 0-300, inclusive); therefore a two-way table would not make sense.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. Rainfall measured is quantitative; therefore a two-way table would not make sense.
